newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigerians free 35 Shell staff, agree to free rest.
newsitem.headline: Nigerians free 35 Shell staff, agree to free rest.

text.p: Nigerian villagers holding 88 staff of oil giant Royal Dutch/Shell hostages have freed 35 and agreed to release the rest on Thursday, a company spokesman said.

"Another 35 Shell staff and contractors were released last night and brought safely back," said the spokesman in Lagos, adding, "Yesterday we met community leaders and an agreement was reached to release all the others today."
Nigerians free 35 Shell staff, agree to free =2

The hostage crisis began last Saturday when Ijaw tribesmen protesting the relocation of their local government headquarters to another town occupied six flow stations of Shell on which they detained 127 staff and contractors, all of them Nigerians.
Negotiations secured the release of the hostages starting with 18 on Monday and by Wednesday there were 88 still held.

The Shell spokesman in Lagos said the negotiations to secure the release of all the hostages had gone smoothly. "Everything is calm. The rest of the staff and contractors should be freed later today," he said.
Three Ijaw tribesmen have died in the protests which escalated into riots in the oil town of Warri on Tuesday while several houses have also been torched.
